title: 114_hr1753
content: The Act may be cited as the "Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015" and establishes the National Office for Cyberspace. The Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015 amends the Federal Information Policy by defining terms like 'Director' and 'information infrastructure' in relation to the National Office for Cyberspace. The Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015 amends the Federal Information Policy by defining terms like 'Director' and 'information infrastructure' in relation to the National Office for Cyberspace. The new paragraphs inserted include reviewing and approving agency information security programs, coordinating defense in case of large-scale attacks, organizing information security training for Federal employees, ensuring privacy and civil liberties protections, and making risk-based security recommendations. The Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015 amends the Federal Information Policy by defining terms like 'Director' and 'information infrastructure' in relation to the National Office for Cyberspace. It includes reviewing and approving agency information security programs, coordinating defense in case of large-scale attacks, organizing information security training for Federal employees, ensuring privacy and civil liberties protections, and making risk-based security recommendations. The Act also mandates ensuring complementary efforts of agencies in developing regulations for the national information infrastructure. The Executive Cyberspace Coordination Act of 2015 amends the Federal Information Policy by defining terms like 'Director' and 'information infrastructure' in relation to the National Office for Cyberspace. It includes reviewing and approving agency information security programs, coordinating defense in case of large-scale attacks, organizing information security training for Federal employees, ensuring privacy and civil liberties protections, and making risk-based security recommendations. The Act also mandates carrying out responsibilities for national security and emergency preparedness communications, as well as other duties relating to the security and resiliency of cyberspace. Additionally, agencies are required to submit a budget each year for the protection of information infrastructure. The Director assesses agency information security programs, compliance with previous plans, and develops a credentialing process for secure authentication. The budget submitted by agencies is assessed and certified for adequacy. The Director assesses agency budgets for information security and makes recommendations to the President based on priorities outlined by the National Office for Cyberspace. The National Office for Cyberspace is established within the Executive Office of the President, with a Director at the helm. The Director is responsible for making recommendations to the President regarding changes in agency organization, management, budget, and personnel allocation related to information infrastructure protection. The National Office for Cyberspace is headed by a Director appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Director administers functions under section 3553, collaborates with agencies, private sector, and international partners, and coordinates cyberspace issues for the Federal Government. The office aims to ensure a secure information infrastructure while promoting national interests, security, and civil liberties. The Director of the National Office for Cyberspace is paid at level III of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional staff and fix their pay, as well as procure temporary services as needed. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the table of sections for subchapter II of chapter 35 of title 44. The Director of the National Office for Cyberspace must establish a national strategy for improving agency information security within one year of the enactment of the Act. This section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after the Act's enactment.
